text: It's a decentralized system that often seems to allow everyone pass the buck and shift the blame to someone else. You need strong leadership on both local + federal level to make it work and ensure housing remains above board.
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
Part of the problem: Housing is almost always considered a "local" issue.

So local authorities get blamed when something bad happens. But it's up to the federal government to oversee & inspect HUD properties funded by federal $ to make sure they are safe.
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
Carbon monoxide killed her father. A $20 detector could have saved his life. But HUD still doesn't require them. 

“He lost his life to something that could have been prevented,” she told me. “My dad was not an animal for them to treat that way.”

text:
Two public housing residents recently died of carbon monoxide poisoning in South Carolina. 

There were no carbon monoxide detectors in their building.

Turns out HUD doesn't require them. 

Why not? My latest investigation: https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/carbon-monoxide-killing-public-housing-residents-hud-doesn-t-require-n977896 …

text: The shutdown's other impacts, big and (very) small:
author: SuzyKhimm

text: USDA has let rural housing for poor Americans fall by the wayside during the shutdown. Landlords aren't getting paid, tenants are afraid of getting evicted, and almost no one is getting answers to basic Qs.  https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/how-shutdown-jeopardizing-housing-rural-americans-n959366 …
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
The Trump admin announced today that it would temporarily re-open USDA offices to help farmers w/business loans, bringing back 2,500 furloughed employees. 

But it isn't doing the same for low-income families who rely on USDA loans, too.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: The lack of information has fueled uncertainty about whether the funding is there, which places strain on landlords and panics tenants who worry about being evicted.
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
Many federal agencies are only providing a trickle of information about the shutdown.

But the USDA has been even worse than others, housing advocates say -- leaving hundreds of thousands of homeowners, landlords, and tenants in the dark. https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/how-shutdown-jeopardizing-housing-rural-americans-n959366 …
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
Scott Mitchell can't afford to buy a house, so he's building one *with his bare hands* thanks to a loan from the USDA. 

Now the shutdown could take away his unfinished home.

USDA's response: "Silence. Crickets."

text:
Reminder: If the shutdown goes past Saturday (1/12), it will be the longest shutdown in U.S. history. 

(The longest one to date was 21 days, during the Clinton years.)
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
There are bad things that normally happen during a government shutdown.

But the Trump administration has made it worse by failing to renew or fund Section 8 contracts that everyone knew were going to expire in Dec/Jan, housing advocates tell me:
author: SuzyKhimm

text: More than 1,100 Section 8 contracts—providing rental assistance for tens of thousands of poor, elderly, and disabled residents—have expired under the shutdown. One source tells me that HUD could have prevented this—but didn’t. https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/because-shutdown-more-1-000-affordable-housing-contracts-have-expired-n955971 …
author: SuzyKhimm

text: It's a complicated relationship -- the local housing authorities (which run public housing and administer Section 8 vouchers) are actually independent, non-profit entities funded by the feds, with close ties to local gov't. But HUD in DC runs other kinds of subsidized housing.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: As @GlennThrush recently reported, landlords across the country are turning away Section 8 voucher holders amid rising rents. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/12/us/politics/section-8-housing-vouchers-landlords.html … I wrote about a different Sec. 8 program, but you can understand why HUD is wary of scaring off landlords in a tight rental market
author: SuzyKhimm

text: All this points to the biggest, most obvious, yet seemingly intractable problem -- the severe shortage of affordable housing that's trapping tenants in awful conditions, makes the gov't hesitant to go HAM on bad landlords, who can then take advantage of everyone.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: But as I explain in the story, HUD is often reluctant to bring the hammer down on private landlords, or come across that way, because it wants and needs them to continue participating in Section 8 & other affordable housing programs.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Other agencies do this very explicitly -- e.g. DOL provides very detailed reports on each investigation of a mine fatalities https://www.msha.gov/data-reports/fatality-reports/search …. Even if you don't want to publicize individual cases, you can publish aggregate stats on enforcement actions taken.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Having this kind of enforcement data is important not just for accountability -- but also because it can serve as a deterrent for bad actors by sending the message that HUD is up to stuff and has its eyes on you.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: It's not even clear that *HUD itself* knows what's going on internally. This new GAO report says HUD no longer tracks certain outcome measures -- like how many residents are now living in acceptable conditions as a result of its enforcement actions. https://www.gao.gov/assets/700/695162.pdf …
author: SuzyKhimm

text: The lack of public data makes it even harder -- for lawmakers, housing advocates, journalists, tenants -- to hold HUD accountable, particularly when it comes to the worst cases/properties/landlords assigned to its enforcement office.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Even then, I couldn't find any HUD enforcement reports prior to Nov. 2017. It turns out that HUD simply *didn't do them* -- even though they were required to under federal laws passed by Congress. As HUD told us: "There are no earlier reports to share."
author: SuzyKhimm

text: It took some real arm-twisting and cajoling to even get these reports from lawmakers. One Hill staffer told me the reports were "proprietary to the committee and not available."
author: SuzyKhimm

text: In response to past scandals surrounding Section 8 living conditions, Congress required HUD to provide lawmakers with regular reports on its enforcement activities and the state of failing government-subsidized properties.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: HUD's enforcement office is tasked with going after the worst landlords and fixing the most appalling housing conditions. But there is almost no comprehensive, publicly available data on what the office is actually doing.
author: SuzyKhimm

text:
There were a lot of shocking things I found while reporting out this story -- appalling housing conditions, federal laws flouted as a matter of routine. 

But I was also flabbergasted by the lack of accountability & transparency at HUD.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Thanks so much, Cezary!
author: SuzyKhimm

text: That domestic labor--like other forms of caregiving--is often invisible and undervalued. But there's a steep toll on families + the economy.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: So Medicaid is our *only* safety net for long-term care. Cuts will put the burden on family caregivers--esp. women.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Obamacare had a pilot program to expand long-term care, but it was scrapped, and nothing's happened since then.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Private long-term care insurance exists, but it's costly and the market is a mess.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: So middle-class families end up having to spend down their savings to qualify for Medicaid -- the only safety net for long-term care.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Average nursing home costs ~$80k/year, full-time home health aide cost ~$22-45k/year, depending on the region.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: Medicare doesn't cover long-term care (nursing homes, home aides) for elderly or disabled. Only Medicaid does. https://twitter.com/7im/status/877950721701720064 …

text: 11. Hydra, the DNC is not…even if DWS had wished otherwise.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 10.  So the idea that the DNC is some all-powerful apparatus run by shadowy evil geniuses is even more absurd now than pre-Obama.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 9....the Obama-era DNC is so underpowered & inept that it couldn’t have swayed the fundamentals of the Dem primary even if it wanted to.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 8. It was obvious even before Wikileaks that DNC was trying to pull for Hillary. But having withered on the vine for the last 8 years...
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 7.  Well before the email stuff came out, the DNC was making utterly headscratching, self-destructive decisions re: debates, for instance.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 6. But the DNC’s dysfunction is clearly also hurting Dems now, in the 2016 races, without a popular charismatic candidate in the lead.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 5. The neglect/indifference of the DNC & the official party apparatus has hurt Dems downballot in the Obama era:
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 4. The DNC was never a priority for Team Obama. That’s why he didn’t bother to replace DWS in 2012 despite grumbling & calls for her to go.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 3. This mentality toward the DNC/party never fundamentally changed even after Obama was elected and became the official head of the party.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 2. Obama 2008 displaced/replaced the DNC as the central organizing apparatus. Obama’s own team was running the ship, not the DNC.
author: SuzyKhimm

text: 1. Party orgs have become increasingly irrelevant as charismatic, well-funded individual candidates have their own campaign infrastructure.
